skill.name: zinc-database
skill.description: Access ZINC (230M+ purchasable compounds). Search by ZINC ID/SMILES, similarity searches, 3D-ready structures for docking, analog discovery, for virtual screening and drug discovery.
skill.summary: Access ZINC (230M+ purchasable compounds). Search by ZINC ID/SMILES, similarity searches, 3D-ready s...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill providing access instructions for the ZINC database. All 364 static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentified scientific terminology (curl commands, tranche codes, database formats) as security threats. This is legitimate educational content about a public academic database maintained by UCSF.

content.value_statement: Finding purchasable compounds for drug discovery is time-consuming and requires specialized database knowledge. This skill provides complete documentation for accessing the ZINC database with 230M+ compounds, enabling efficient virtual screening, similarity searches, and 3D structure downloads for molecular docking studies.
actual_capabilities: Search compounds by ZINC ID or SMILES structure notation
Perform similarity searches with configurable distance thresholds
Generate random compound samples filtered by drug-likeness
Access 3D molecular structures for molecular docking
Query compounds by supplier catalog codes
Filter results by molecular properties (MW, LogP, H-bond donors)
limitations: Requires internet connection to access ZINC API endpoints
Does not perform molecular modeling or docking calculations
No built-in compound visualization or analysis tools
Availability of compounds depends on supplier catalogs

use_cases.title: Prepare docking libraries
use_cases.description: Download drug-like compounds in bulk for virtual screening campaigns with molecular docking software.

use_cases.title: Find purchasable analogs
use_cases.description: Search for commercially available analogs of known hit compounds to accelerate lead optimization.

use_cases.title: Explore chemical space
use_cases.description: Sample diverse chemical libraries to identify novel lead compounds for therapeutic targets.

prompt_templates.title: Simple compound lookup
prompt_templates.prompt: Find information about compound ZINC000000000001 in the ZINC database. Include SMILES, supplier information, and molecular properties.

prompt_templates.title: Similarity search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search ZINC for compounds similar to aspirin (SMILES: CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O) with Tanimoto distance of 3. Return the first 20 results with ZINC IDs and SMILES.

prompt_templates.title: Docking library prep
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a list of 5000 drug-like compounds from ZINC22. Filter for MW between 350-500, LogP less than 5, and 0 H-bond donors. Include ZINC IDs and tranche codes.

prompt_templates.title: Analog discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Find purchasable analogs of a hit compound with SMILES CCN(CC)CCNC(=O)C1=CC=C(C=C1)N(CC)CC. Use similarity search with distance 4. Return ZINC IDs, SMILES, and supplier catalogs.

output_examples.input: Find 10 random lead-like compounds from ZINC
output: Molecular weight range: 250-350 Da, LogP 3.5 or less
Results include ZINC IDs and SMILES strings
Each compound includes tranche code for property filtering
Supplier catalogs listed for purchasing information

output_examples.input: Search for similar compounds to ibuprofen
output: Found 50 similar compounds to ibuprofen SMILES
Results sorted by similarity with ZINC IDs and structures
Supplier availability shown for each compound
Tranche codes enable additional property filtering

best_practices: Start with exact SMILES searches before expanding to similarity searches for more precise results
Use tranche filtering (H-count, LogP, MW) to reduce search space before detailed analysis
Cache frequently accessed compounds locally to minimize API calls and respect rate limits
anti_patterns: Making rapid consecutive requests without delays - this may trigger rate limiting
Requesting all output fields when only specific data is needed - increases response size
Using overly broad similarity searches without property filters - returns excessive results

faq.question: What is the difference between ZINC22, ZINC20, and ZINC15?
faq.answer: ZINC22 is the current version with 230M+ compounds. ZINC20 focuses on lead-like and drug-like compounds. ZINC15 is legacy but still documented. Use ZINC22 for the most comprehensive search.

faq.question: How many compounds can I retrieve in a single query?
faq.answer: The API returns up to 100 compounds by default. For bulk downloads, use the file repository which contains tranche-based downloads in DB2, MOL2, and SDF formats.

faq.question: Can I use this with RDKit or other cheminformatics tools?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill provides Python examples showing how to integrate ZINC queries with RDKit for property calculation, 3D conformer generation, and SDF export.

faq.question: Is the data safe to use for research publications?
faq.answer: ZINC data comes from supplier catalogs and may change. Always verify compound availability and structure validity. Cite the appropriate ZINC publication in your work.

faq.question: Why am I getting empty results from my search?
faq.answer: Check your SMILES syntax for errors. Verify ZINC IDs are valid. For similarity searches, try increasing the distance parameter.

faq.question: How does this compare to PubChem or ChEMBL?
faq.answer: ZINC specializes in purchasable compounds with pre-filtered subsets. PubChem and ChEMBL are larger but include many unavailable compounds. ZINC excels for virtual screening.
